mn146:1.1.comm: This discourse deals with the fortnightly teaching of the nuns, a practice ostensibly set up at Mahāpajāpati’s ordination (AN 8.51:13.1, Kd 20:1.4.7) and mandated in the Vinaya (Bu Pc 21, Bi Pc 59). This is the only mention of such a teaching in the discourses. However it does not follow the pattern laid out in the Vinaya, where the teaching consists of the eight garudhammas (Bi Pc 58), and the monks cannot go to the nuns’ monastery to advise them (Bu Pc 23).

mn146:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn146:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn146:2.1.pli: Atha kho mahāpajāpatigotamī pañcamattehi bhikkhunisatehi saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho mahāpajāpatigotamī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn146:2.1.eng: Then Mahāpajāpati Gotamī together with around five hundred nuns approached the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
mn146:2.1.comm: Here we see Mahāpajāpati in the leadership role that would be expected were she the founder of the nuns. However, this is the only case where this occurs.

mn146:2.4.pli: karotu, bhante, bhagavā bhikkhunīnaṃ dhammiṃ kathan”ti.
mn146:2.4.eng: Please give the nuns a Dhamma talk.”

mn146:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena therā bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo ovadanti pariyāyena.
mn146:3.1.eng: Now at that time the senior monks were taking turns to advise the nuns.
mn146:3.1.comm: Monks must be appointed by the Saṅgha to take on this role, and they must fulfill eight factors: they must be virtuous and learned, have memorized both Monastic Codes, be well-spoken, liked by the nuns, and capable, never having committed a heavy offense against a nun; and they must have been ordained at least twenty years (Bu Pc 21).

mn146:3.2.pli: Āyasmā nandako na icchati bhikkhuniyo ovadituṃ pariyāyena.
mn146:3.2.eng: But Venerable Nandaka didn’t want to take his turn.
mn146:3.2.comm: Nandaka was praised for his teaching of monks (AN 9.4). At AN 3.66 he taught the layman Sāḷha how to discern the true teaching, using the method of questioning as he does in the present discourse. On the strength of this teaching, Nandaka was declared the foremost in advising nuns (AN 1.229:1.1). His four Theragāthā verses are at Thag 4.4 according to the commentary. A second Nandaka at Thag 2.27 was the brother of Bharata (Thag 2.28). | While the text does not explain why he was reluctant to teach, the commentary says that those nuns were his wives in past lives and he wanted to avoid the potential for gossip.

mn146:3.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn146:3.3.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,

mn146:3.4.pli: “kassa nu kho, ānanda, ajja pariyāyo bhikkhuniyo ovadituṃ pariyāyenā”ti?
mn146:3.4.eng: “Ānanda, whose turn is it to advise the nuns today?”

mn146:3.5.pli: “Sabbeheva, bhante, kato pariyāyo bhikkhuniyo ovadituṃ pariyāyena.

mn146:3.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhante, āyasmā nandako na icchati bhikkhuniyo ovadituṃ pariyāyenā”ti.
mn146:3.6.eng: but he doesn’t want to do it.”

mn146:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ āmantesi:
mn146:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Nandaka,

mn146:4.4.pli: karohi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhunīnaṃ dhammiṃ kathan”ti.
mn146:4.4.eng: Please, brahmin, give the nuns a Dhamma talk.”

mn146:4.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā nandako bhagavato paṭissutvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn146:4.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Nandaka. Then, in the morning, he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

mn146:4.6.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto attadutiyo yena rājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
mn146:4.6.eng: He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Royal Monastery with a companion.
mn146:4.6.comm: The Royal Monastery (rājakārāma) was a residence for nuns near Sāvatthī, also featured in SN 55.11.

mn146:4.7.pli: Addasaṃsu kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn146:4.7.eng: Those nuns saw him coming off in the distance,

mn146:4.8.pli: Disvāna āsanaṃ paññāpesuṃ, udakañca pādānaṃ upaṭṭhapesuṃ.
mn146:4.8.eng: so they spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.

mn146:4.9.pli: Nisīdi kho āyasmā nandako paññatte āsane.
mn146:4.9.eng: Nandaka sat down on the seat spread out,

mn146:4.11.pli: Tāpi kho bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mn146:4.11.eng: Those nuns bowed, and sat down to one side.

mn146:4.12.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmā nandako etadavoca:

mn146:5.1.eng: “Sisters, this talk shall be in the form of questions.

mn146:5.2.pli: Tattha ājānantīhi: ‘ājānāmā’ tissa vacanīyaṃ, na ājānantīhi: ‘na ājānāmā’ tissa vacanīyaṃ.
mn146:5.2.eng: When you understand, say so. When you don’t understand, say so.

mn146:5.3.pli: Yassā vā panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā ahameva tattha paṭipucchitabbo:
mn146:5.3.eng: If anyone has a doubt or uncertainty, ask me about it:

mn146:5.4.eng: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’”
mn146:5.4.comm: Nandaka does not lecture the nuns, but engages with them. He makes it clear that, against patriarchal expectations, the nuns should ask for clarifications.

mn146:5.5.pli: “Ettakenapi mayaṃ, bhante, ayyassa nandakassa attamanā abhiraddhā yaṃ no ayyo nandako pavāretī”ti.
mn146:5.5.eng: “We’re already delighted and satisfied with Master Nandaka, since he invites us like this.”
mn146:5.5.comm: Thus fulfilling one of the factors required for a teacher of nuns.

mn146:6.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
mn146:6.2.comm: The discussion begins with the most obvious factors, the internal sense organs, and proceeds to analyze each in terms of the three characteristics: impermanence, suffering, and not-self. Nandaka ensures that the nuns are with him each step.

mn146:6.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn146:6.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn146:6.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn146:6.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn146:6.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn146:6.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn146:6.20.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn146:6.22.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn146:6.22.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn146:6.23.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn146:6.26.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:
mn146:6.26.eng: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:

mn146:6.27.eng: ‘So these six interior sense fields are impermanent.’”
mn146:6.27.comm: This level of direct insight normally indicates stream-entry. See below at MN 146:27.5.

mn146:6.29.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.
mn146:6.29.eng: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

mn146:7.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn146:7.4.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

mn146:7.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn146:7.6.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:

mn146:7.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn146:7.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn146:7.20.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

mn146:7.22.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn146:7.22.eng: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:

mn146:7.23.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn146:7.26.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:
mn146:7.26.eng: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:

mn146:7.27.eng: ‘So these six exterior sense fields are impermanent.’”

mn146:7.29.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.
mn146:7.29.eng: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

mn146:8.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:8.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:8.9.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, sotaviññāṇaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:8.19.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vāti”?
mn146:8.19.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn146:8.21.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn146:8.21.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn146:8.22.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn146:8.25.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:
mn146:8.25.eng: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:

mn146:8.26.eng: ‘So these six classes of consciousness are impermanent.’”

mn146:8.28.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.
mn146:8.28.eng: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

mn146:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, ābhāpi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā.
mn146:9.1.eng: Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The oil, wick, flame, and light were all impermanent and perishable.
mn146:9.1.comm: While the imagery of the dependence of the flame on its fuel is common in the suttas, this exact metaphor is not found elsewhere. Normally the Buddha employs metaphors in an ABA structure: he explains the doctrine, illustrates it, and repeats the explanation. Here, however, the metaphor acts as a springboard for the next stage of the argument, the impermanence of feelings.

mn146:9.2.pli: Yo nu kho, bhaginiyo, evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:9.2.eng: Now, suppose someone was to say:

mn146:9.3.pli: ‘amussa telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā;
mn146:9.3.eng: ‘While this oil lamp is burning, the oil, the wick, and the flame are all impermanent and perishable.

mn146:9.4.pli: yā ca khvāssa ābhā sā niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā’ti;
mn146:9.4.eng: But the light is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

mn146:9.5.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:9.8.pli: “Amussa hi, bhante, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā;
mn146:9.8.eng: Because that oil lamp’s oil, wick, and flame are all impermanent and perishable,

mn146:9.9.comm: The Self is often said to be a light (eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.7).

mn146:9.10.pli: “Evameva kho, bhaginiyo, yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:9.10.eng: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

mn146:9.11.eng: ‘These six interior sense fields are impermanent.

mn146:9.12.pli: yañca kho cha ajjhattike āyatane paṭicca paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā taṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhamman’ti;
mn146:9.12.eng: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six interior sense fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

mn146:9.13.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:9.16.pli: “Tajjaṃ tajjaṃ, bhante, paccayaṃ paṭicca tajjā tajjā vedanā uppajjanti.
mn146:9.16.eng: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.

mn146:9.17.pli: Tajjassa tajjassa paccayassa nirodhā tajjā tajjā vedanā nirujjhantī”ti.
mn146:9.17.eng: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”

mn146:9.19.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.
mn146:9.19.eng: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

mn146:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, chāyāpi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā.
mn146:10.1.eng: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, branches and leaves, and shadow were all impermanent and perishable.
mn146:10.1.comm: This is another unique application of a familiar image, although a similar metaphor for the six senses as the shadow of a post is found at AN 4.195:11.1.

mn146:10.2.pli: Yo nu kho, bhaginiyo, evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:10.2.eng: Now, suppose someone was to say:

mn146:10.3.pli: ‘amussa mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, yā ca khvāssa chāyā sā niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā’ti;
mn146:10.3.eng: ‘There’s a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable. But the shadow is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

mn146:10.4.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:10.7.pli: “Amussa hi, bhante, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ;
mn146:10.7.eng: Because that large tree’s roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable,

mn146:10.8.comm: Divinity is identified, albeit inadequately, with a shadow at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.12. From Vedic times the shadow was both the place of relief from the hot sun (Rig Veda 6.16.38, 2.33.6) and the shadow of death (10.121.2).

mn146:10.9.pli: “Evameva kho, bhaginiyo, yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:10.9.eng: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

mn146:10.10.eng: ‘These six exterior sense fields are impermanent.
mn146:10.10.comm: The metaphor of shadow for the exterior sense fields is the inverse of that for the interior sense fields, light. This speaks to the high degree of care with which Nandaka structured his teaching. Further, the movement from light to shadow subconsciously prepares the audience for the darker metaphor to come.

mn146:10.11.pli: Yañca kho cha bāhire āyatane paṭicca paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā taṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhamman’ti;
mn146:10.11.eng: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six exterior sense fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

mn146:10.12.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:10.15.pli: “Tajjaṃ tajjaṃ, bhante, paccayaṃ paṭicca tajjā tajjā vedanā uppajjanti.
mn146:10.15.eng: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.

mn146:10.16.pli: Tajjassa tajjassa paccayassa nirodhā tajjā tajjā vedanā nirujjhantī”ti.
mn146:10.16.eng: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”

mn146:10.18.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.
mn146:10.18.eng: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.

mn146:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā tiṇhena govikantanena gāviṃ saṅkanteyya anupahacca antaraṃ maṃsakāyaṃ anupahacca bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ.
mn146:11.1.eng: Suppose a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver. Without damaging the flesh inside or the hide outside,
mn146:11.1.comm: A similar image is applied to analysis by way of the elements (MN 10:12.3 = MN 119:8.3).

mn146:11.2.pli: Yaṃ yadeva tattha antarā vilimaṃsaṃ antarā nhāru antarā bandhanaṃ taṃ tadeva tiṇhena govikantanena sañchindeyya saṅkanteyya sampakanteyya samparikanteyya.
mn146:11.2.eng: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments with a sharp meat cleaver,

mn146:11.3.pli: Sañchinditvā saṅkantitvā sampakantitvā samparikantitvā vidhunitvā bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ teneva cammena taṃ gāviṃ paṭicchādetvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:11.3.eng: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:

mn146:11.4.eng: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’

mn146:11.5.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:11.8.pli: “Amu hi, bhante, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā tiṇhena govikantanena gāviṃ saṅkanteyya anupahacca antaraṃ maṃsakāyaṃ anupahacca bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ.

mn146:11.9.pli: Yaṃ yadeva tattha antarā vilimaṃsaṃ antarā nhāru antarā bandhanaṃ taṃ tadeva tiṇhena govikantanena sañchindeyya saṅkanteyya sampakanteyya samparikanteyya.

mn146:11.10.pli: Sañchinditvā saṅkantitvā sampakantitvā samparikantitvā vidhunitvā bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ teneva cammena taṃ gāviṃ paṭicchādetvā kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya:
mn146:11.10.eng: Because even if they wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:

mn146:11.11.eng: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before,’

mn146:11.12.pli: atha kho sā gāvī visaṃyuttā teneva cammenā”ti.
mn146:11.12.eng: still that cow is not joined to that hide.”

mn146:12.1.pli: “Upamā kho me ayaṃ, bhaginiyo, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
mn146:12.1.eng: “I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

mn146:12.3.pli: ‘antarā maṃsakāyo’ti kho, bhaginiyo, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ;
mn146:12.3.eng: ‘The inner flesh’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.

mn146:12.4.pli: ‘bāhiro cammakāyo’ti kho, bhaginiyo, channetaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ;
mn146:12.4.eng: ‘The outer hide’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.

mn146:12.5.pli: ‘antarā vilimaṃsaṃ, antarā nhāru, antarā bandhanan’ti kho, bhaginiyo, nandīrāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ;
mn146:12.5.eng: ‘The connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments’ is a term for greed and relishing.

mn146:12.6.pli: ‘tiṇhaṃ govikantanan’ti kho, bhaginiyo, ariyāyetaṃ paññāya adhivacanaṃ;
mn146:12.6.eng: ‘A sharp meat cleaver’ is a term for noble wisdom.

mn146:12.7.pli: yāyaṃ ariyā paññā antarā kilesaṃ antarā saṃyojanaṃ antarā bandhanaṃ sañchindati saṅkantati sampakantati samparikantati.
mn146:12.7.eng: And it is that noble wisdom which cuts, carves, severs, and slices the connecting corruption, fetter, and bond.

mn146:13.1.pli: Satta kho panime, bhaginiyo, bojjhaṅgā, yesaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
mn146:13.1.eng: Sisters, by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
mn146:13.1.comm: Knowing that the nuns have good insight, Nandaka encourages them to continue deepening their meditation practice.

mn146:13.3.pli: Idha, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
mn146:13.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,

mn146:13.9.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
mn146:13.9.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

mn146:13.10.pli: Ime kho, bhaginiyo, satta bojjhaṅgā, yesaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
mn146:13.10.eng: It is by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

mn146:14.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nandako tā bhikkhuniyo iminā ovādena ovaditvā uyyojesi:
mn146:14.1.eng: Then after giving this advice to the nuns, Nandaka sent them off, saying,

mn146:14.2.comm: This seems at odds with the detail that Nandaka had gone to the nuns’ monastery to teach. Parallels in Chinese and Tibetan say instead that Nandaka left ( SA 276 at T ii 75c2; T 1442 at T xxiii 793c12, and D (3) ’dul ba, ja 57b7).

mn146:14.3.pli: Atha kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmato nandakassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhagavā etadavoca:
mn146:14.3.eng: And then those nuns approved and agreed with what Nandaka had said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right. Then they went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to them,

mn146:14.5.pli: Atha kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
mn146:14.5.eng: Then those nuns bowed to the Buddha respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

mn146:15.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantīsu tāsu bhikkhunīsu bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn146:15.1.eng: Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

mn146:15.2.pli: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tadahuposathe cātuddase na hoti bahuno janassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā:
mn146:15.2.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fourteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people

mn146:15.3.pli: ‘ūno nu kho cando, puṇṇo nu kho cando’ti, atha kho ūno cando tveva hoti.
mn146:15.3.eng: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously not full.

mn146:15.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tā bhikkhuniyo nandakassa dhammadesanāya attamanā honti no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappā”ti.
mn146:15.4.eng: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, but they still haven’t got all they wished for.”

mn146:16.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ āmantesi:
mn146:16.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Nandaka,

mn146:16.2.pli: “tena hi tvaṃ, nandaka, svepi tā bhikkhuniyo tenevovādena ovadeyyāsī”ti.
mn146:16.2.eng: “Well then, Nandaka, tomorrow you should give those nuns the same advice again.”

mn146:16.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā nandako bhagavato paccassosi.

mn146:16.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nandako tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn146:16.4.eng: And the next day he went to those nuns, and all unfolded just like the previous day.

mn146:16.5.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto attadutiyo yena rājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.

mn146:16.6.pli: Addasaṃsu kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.

mn146:16.7.pli: Disvāna āsanaṃ paññāpesuṃ, udakañca pādānaṃ upaṭṭhapesuṃ.

mn146:16.8.pli: Nisīdi kho āyasmā nandako paññatte āsane.

mn146:16.10.pli: Tāpi kho bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.

mn146:16.11.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmā nandako etadavoca:

mn146:16.13.pli: Tattha ājānantīhi ‘ājānāmā’ tissa vacanīyaṃ, na ājānantīhi ‘na ājānāmā’ tissa vacanīyaṃ.

mn146:16.14.pli: Yassā vā panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, ahameva tattha paṭipucchitabbo:

mn146:16.16.pli: “Ettakenapi mayaṃ, bhante, ayyassa nandakassa attamanā abhiraddhā yaṃ no ayyo nandako pavāretī”ti.

mn146:17-18.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, cakkhu niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:17-18.3.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:17-18.5.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:17-18.8.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, sotaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:17-18.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:17-18.18.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:17-18.22.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:

mn146:17-18.25.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.

mn146:19-20.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, rūpā niccā vā aniccā vā”ti?

mn146:19-20.3.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:19-20.5.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:19-20.8.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, saddā niccā vā aniccā vā”ti?

mn146:19-20.18.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:19-20.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:19-20.24.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:

mn146:19-20.27.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.

mn146:21.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhaginiyo, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:21.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

mn146:21.15.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:

mn146:21.19.pli: “Pubbeva no etaṃ, bhante, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ:

mn146:21.22.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.

mn146:22.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, ābhāpi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā.

mn146:22.2.pli: Yo nu kho, bhaginiyo, evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:22.3.pli: ‘amussa telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā;

mn146:22.4.pli: yā ca khvāssa ābhā sā niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā’ti;

mn146:22.5.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:22.8.pli: “Amussa hi, bhante, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, vaṭṭipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā, accipi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā;

mn146:22.10.pli: “Evameva kho, bhaginiyo, yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:22.12.pli: Yañca kho cha ajjhattike āyatane paṭicca paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā taṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhamman’ti;

mn146:22.13.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:22.16.pli: “Tajjaṃ tajjaṃ, bhante, paccayaṃ paṭicca tajjā tajjā vedanā uppajjanti.

mn146:22.17.pli: Tajjassa tajjassa paccayassa nirodhā tajjā tajjā vedanā nirujjhantī”ti.

mn146:22.19.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.

mn146:23.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, chāyāpi aniccā vipariṇāmadhammā.

mn146:23.2.pli: Yo nu kho, bhaginiyo, evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:23.3.pli: ‘amussa mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ;

mn146:23.4.pli: yā ca khvāssa chāyā sā niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā’ti;

mn146:23.5.pli: sammā nu kho so bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:23.8.pli: “Amussa hi, bhante, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato mūlampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, khandhopi anicco vipariṇāmadhammo, sākhāpalāsampi aniccaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ;

mn146:23.10.pli: “Evameva kho, bhaginiyo, yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:23.12.pli: Yañca kho bāhire āyatane paṭicca paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā taṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhamman’ti;

mn146:23.13.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:23.16.pli: “Tajjaṃ tajjaṃ, bhante, paccayaṃ paṭicca tajjā tajjā vedanā uppajjanti.

mn146:23.17.pli: Tajjassa tajjassa paccayassa nirodhā tajjā tajjā vedanā nirujjhantī”ti.

mn146:23.19.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhaginiyo, hoti ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato.

mn146:24.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhaginiyo, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā tiṇhena govikantanena gāviṃ saṅkanteyya anupahacca antaraṃ maṃsakāyaṃ anupahacca bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ.

mn146:24.2.pli: Yaṃ yadeva tattha antarā vilimaṃsaṃ antarā nhāru antarā bandhanaṃ taṃ tadeva tiṇhena govikantanena sañchindeyya saṅkanteyya sampakanteyya samparikanteyya.

mn146:24.3.pli: Sañchinditvā saṅkantitvā sampakantitvā samparikantitvā vidhunitvā bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ teneva cammena taṃ gāviṃ paṭicchādetvā evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:24.5.pli: sammā nu kho so, bhaginiyo, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

mn146:24.8.pli: “Amu hi, bhante, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā tiṇhena govikantanena gāviṃ saṅkanteyya anupahacca antaraṃ maṃsakāyaṃ anupahacca bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ.

mn146:24.9.pli: Yaṃ yadeva tattha antarā vilimaṃsaṃ antarā nhāru antarā bandhanaṃ taṃ tadeva tiṇhena govikantanena sañchindeyya saṅkanteyya sampakanteyya samparikanteyya.

mn146:24.10.pli: Sañchinditvā saṅkantitvā sampakantitvā samparikantitvā vidhunitvā bāhiraṃ cammakāyaṃ teneva cammena taṃ gāviṃ paṭicchādetvā kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya:

mn146:24.12.pli: atha kho sā gāvī visaṃyuttā teneva cammenā”ti.

mn146:25.1.pli: “Upamā kho me ayaṃ, bhaginiyo, katā atthassa viññāpanāya ayamevettha attho.

mn146:25.2.pli: ‘Antarā maṃsakāyo’ti kho, bhaginiyo, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ;

mn146:25.3.pli: ‘bāhiro cammakāyo’ti kho, bhaginiyo, channetaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ;

mn146:25.4.pli: ‘antarā vilimaṃsaṃ antarā nhāru antarā bandhanan’ti kho, bhaginiyo, nandīrāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ;

mn146:25.5.pli: ‘tiṇhaṃ govikantanan’ti kho, bhaginiyo, ariyāyetaṃ paññāya adhivacanaṃ;

mn146:25.6.pli: yāyaṃ ariyā paññā antarā kilesaṃ antarā saṃyojanaṃ antarā bandhanaṃ sañchindati saṅkantati sampakantati samparikantati.

mn146:26.1.pli: Satta kho panime, bhaginiyo, bojjhaṅgā, yesaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.

mn146:26.3.pli: Idha, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.

mn146:26.9.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.

mn146:26.10.pli: Ime kho, bhaginiyo, satta bojjhaṅgā yesaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.

mn146:26.11.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nandako tā bhikkhuniyo iminā ovādena ovaditvā uyyojesi:

mn146:26.13.pli: Atha kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmato nandakassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhagavā etadavoca:

mn146:26.15.pli: Atha kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.

mn146:27.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantīsu tāsu bhikkhunīsu bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn146:27.1.eng: Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

mn146:27.2.pli: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tadahuposathe pannarase na hoti bahuno janassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā:
mn146:27.2.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fifteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people

mn146:27.3.pli: ‘ūno nu kho cando, puṇṇo nu kho cando’ti, atha kho puṇṇo cando tveva hoti;
mn146:27.3.eng: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously full.

mn146:27.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, tā bhikkhuniyo nandakassa dhammadesanāya attamanā ceva paripuṇṇasaṅkappā ca.
mn146:27.4.eng: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, and they got all they wished for.

mn146:27.5.pli: Tāsaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ bhikkhunisatānaṃ yā pacchimikā bhikkhunī sā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyanā”ti.
mn146:27.5.eng: Even the last of these five hundred nuns is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”
mn146:27.5.comm: As noted above, the nuns’ statements indicate that they had attained stream-entry even before being taught by Nandaka. Elsewhere, to have fulfilled one’s wishes like the moon on the fifteenth day unequivocally means arahantship (Thag 10.2:10.1). Indeed, parallels indicate that at this point they have all attained arahantship (SA 276 at T ii 75c16; T 1442 at T xxiii 794a14; D (3) ’dul ba, ja 59a1). Remarkably, this detail is also confirmed in the commentaries to the Aṅguttara Nikāya, Theragāthā, and Therīgāthā, which say they became arahants when listening to Nandaka’s second teaching.

mn146:27.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn146:27.7.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn146:27.7.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
